Body: As we know, the internal nand flash have many partitions, such as for bootloader, boot, system, data,  recovery, cache, misc, but there is no partition for radio.However, one can upgrade the base-band firmware by flashing radio.img.Where is the location to store radio.img?I know the 2G/3G's sending/reception are done by a dedicated chip, say Cortex-R4.So I speculate: There must be a dedicated nand flash for Cortex-R4. The nand flash can only be accessed by the bootloader, and separated from the normal nand flash.Am I correct?
Title: Is there a dedicated Nand-Flash for the base-band chip?

history.Text: As we know, the internal nand flash have many partitions, such as for bootloader, boot, system, data,  recovery, cache, misc, but there is no partition for radio.However, one can upgrade the base-band firmware by flashing radio.img.Where is the location to store radio.img?I know the 3G/3G's sending/reception are done by a dedicated chip, say Cortex-R4.So I speculate: There must be a dedicated nand flash for Cortex-R4. The nand flash can only be accessed by the bootloader, and separated from the normal nand flash.Am I correct?
Is there a dedicated Nand-Flash for the base-band chip?

As we know, the internal nand flash have many partitions, such as for bootloader, boot, system, data,  recovery, cache, misc, but there is no partition for radio.However, one can upgrade the base-band firmware by flashing radio.img.Where is the location to store radio.img?I know the 2G/3G's sending/reception are done by a dedicated chip, say Cortex-R4.So I speculate: There must be a dedicated nand flash for Cortex-R4. The nand flash can only be accessed by the bootloader, and separated from the normal nand flash.Am I correct?
